sorry.. A is correct...
An NSX virtual switch (N-VDS or VDS with NSX) can attach to a single overlay transport zone and multiple VLAN transport zones at the same time.
A transport zone can only be attached to a single NSX virtual switch on a given transport node. In other words, two NSX virtual switches on the same transport node cannot be attached to the same transport zone.
https://communities.vmware.com/t5/VMware-NSX-Documents/VMware-NSX-T-Reference-Design/ta-p/2778093?attachment-id=102745

discussion.content: D is correct...when you prepare an ESXi host or create un TN Profile, you can select multiple TZ for a single N-VDS that will be connected to ESXi.

http://www.vmwarearena.com/how-to-create-nsx-t-transport-zone-vmware-nsx-t-part-7/

"You can use the same N-VDS to link to multiple transport zones. I.e Single N-VDS can carry the traffic of both the Overlay transport zone and the VLAN transport zone."

comments.content: This is realy hard question. I'm not sure which answer is good for 100%. We can create only single N-VDS per TZ. But it doesn't say that we can't use the same N-VDS in couple of TZs. In the table attached to this question we can see that every N-VDS has the same name. So the most probably answer is D.

discussion.content: A is the good answer. TZ is more general object then N-VDS. So you need to create N-VDS for each TZ you want to have active/usable on the esxi host.

Correct Answer is D:

See this link - https://docs.pivotal.io/pks/1-5/nsxt-install-create-tns.html 

About Transport Nodes

In NSX-T transport nodes are the hosts running the local control plane daemons and forwarding engines implementing the NSX-T data plane. A transport node runs a NSX-T Virtual Distributed Switch (N-VDS) that is responsible for switching packets according to the configuration of available network services.

A host can serve as a transport node if it contains at least one NSX-T-managed virtual distributed switch (N-VDS). When you create a host transport node and then add the node to a transport zone, NSX-T Data Center installs an N-VDS on the host. For each transport zone that the host belongs to, a separate N-VDS is installed. The N-VDS is used for attaching VMs to NSX-T Data Center logical switches and for creating NSX-T Data Center logical router uplinks and downlinks.

I think the D is correct simply because when join transport node to these Transport Zones TZ, these TZ will create these N-VDS into the Host, now N-VDS can only support only one type of traffic either overlay or VLAN, and Esxi host can not have two N-VDS with the Same name, but one N-VDS on Esxi host can attach to Overlay and VLAN simultaneously. so 1 N-VDS on Esxi will be sufficient. and 2 can not be created as here both TZ traffic type Overlay and VLAN has the same switch name. Thats my understanding i would be thankful if someone endorse it?

A and C are both correct , but C is more specific for NSX-T environment, than A that is a general KVM command:
https://vdc-download.vmware.com/vmwb-repository/dcr-public/46158b4f-e75f-49a6-8014-056750afa658/a944ad7a-6043-41d7-91a2-99f602996c77/NSX-T%20Command-Line%20Interface%20Reference.html#set%20capture%20session%20%3Csession-number%3E%20[file%20%3Cfilename%3E]%20[count%20%3Cpacket-count%3E]%20[expression%20%3Cexpression%3E]

https://www.simongreaves.co.uk/nsx-t-cli-reference-guide/

I am pretty sure those guys who answered on original exam already well thought out. They answer Correct one and no additional input are need unless very helpful one.

Set capture is an answer

To run the packet capture using this configuration, use the set capture session <session-number> [file <filename>] [count <packet-count>] [expression <expression>] command.

Usage and Example
kvm-1> set capture session 1 interface b592a7c8-4e21-493e-b0fc-0b1d152c949c direction both
kvm-1> get capture session 1
Packet Capture Session
ID : 1
PORTS : ['b592a7c8-4e21-493e-b0fc-0b1d152c949c']
Mode
Basic
Availability
KVM

Ref: https://vdc-download.vmware.com/vmwb-repository/dcr-public/46158b4f-e75f-49a6-8014-056750afa658/a944ad7a-6043-41d7-91a2-99f602996c77/NSX-T%20Command-Line%20Interface%20Reference.html#set%20capture%20session%20%3Csession-number%3E

Which two steps must an NSX administrator take to integrate VMware Identity Manager in NSX-T to support role-based access control? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Create an OAuth 2.0 client in VMware Identity Manager.
choices.A: Add NSX Manager as a Service Provider (SP) in VMware Identity Manager.
choices.D: Create a SAML authentication in VMware Identity Manager using the NSX Manager FQDN.
choices.E: Enter the Identity Provider (IdP) metadata URL in NSX Manager.
choices.C: Enter the service URL, Client Secret, and SSL thumbprint in NSX Manager.

questions.question_text:

choices.B: esxcli network ip interface ipv4 get
